Later on, accordingly, when Megalius, Bishop ol Calama, and at that time primate oi Numidia, had come athis request to visit the church at Hippo, unexpectedly to all the bishop Valerius made his desire lmown to the bishops who happened at that time to be present, and to all the clergy of Hippo and to all the people. But while all who heard rejoiced and clamored most eugerly that tbis should be done and accomplished, the presbyter refused to accept the episcopate contrary to the custom of the Church, since his bishop was still living. However, when they had con- vinced him that this was generally done and had appealed to examples from the churches across the sea as well as in Africa, though he had been ignorant ol it before, under com- pulsion and constraint he yielded and accepted the ordination to the higher office. Later he both said and wrote that this should not have been done in his case, namely to ordain him while his bishop was still living, because ol the prohibition of the Ecumenical Council of which he learned alter his ordi· nati0n; for that which he regretted to have had done in his case he did not wish to have done to others.
